awd_titl_txt: Strong Gravitational Lensing at High Spectral Resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Gravitational lensing occurs when light from a distant galaxy is bent by gravity from another galaxy along the line of sight.  The light is stretched over a larger area on the sky, making the background galaxy appear brighter but distorting its shape.  A traditional way to study the background galaxies and foreground lenses is to apply theoretical models to observations with high angular resolution.  The goal of this project is to apply new theoretical models to observations with high resolution, like those made by radio telescopes.  The PI (a theorist) and Co-PI (an observer) will work with Rutgers graduate and undergraduate students to achieve this goal.  The project will support prior U.S. investments in large arrays of radio telescopes and improve the understanding of dark matter, black holes, and galaxy evolution.  The project will also train students in research, including rising sophomores from disadvantaged backgrounds.

This project will introduce a new way to model data from NSF's Very Large Array, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, and similar facilities.  The new method will be implemented in the PI's public lensmodel software package.  It will be applied to both compact and extended lenses in two types of distant galaxies.  With lensed quasar host galaxies the project will examine the evolution of black hole scaling relations.  With lensed dusty star-forming galaxies the project will examine an extreme mode of star formation.  The resulting models will be used to characterize lens-plane substructure and test the cold dark matter structure formation paradigm.  In addition to training graduate students, the PI and Co-PI will introduce undergraduate students to research through a new seminar course for first-year Educational Opportunity Fund students at Rutgers.  This class will combine professional development, biographical material on scientists and engineers from diverse backgrounds, and hands-on research activities.

por.por_cntn:
Gravitational lensing occurs when light from a distant source is bent by the gravity of some mass distribution (e.g., a galaxy or cluster of galaxies) that lies along the line of sight. From our point of view, the light is then stretched over a larger area on the sky, making the background source appear brighter but distorting its shape. A traditional way to study both background sources and foreground lenses is to derive models that can fit observations with high angular resolution. This project developed a new technique for deriving models that can fit observations with high spectral (i.e., frequency or wavelength) resolution -- like those that are typically produced by modern radio telescopes -- through collaboration between a theorist (the PI), an observer (the Co-PI), and their graduate and undergraduate students.

The ten refereed papers published as part of this project have reported results that include the following:

  • Forecasts for using gravitational lenses to distinguish between cold and warm dark matter scenarios (Gilman et al. 2018; Brennan et al. 2019), and development of a new framework for lens modeling intended to measure the power spectrum of small-scale density fluctuations in lens galaxies (Cyr-Racine et al. 2019). 
  • Presentation of results from a pilot program for z-GAL, which is a redshift survey of the brightest dusty star-forming galaxies identified by the Herschel Space Observatory, nearly all of which are expected to be lensed (Neri et al. 2020).
  • Analysis of the lensed quasar J043947.08+163415.7 at redshift z = 6.51, which is the first such system at z > 5 (Fan et al. 2019; Yang et al. 2019; Yue et al. 2021). 
  • Analysis of the doubly-imaged system HerBS-89, which is revealed to be a member of the relatively rare category of dusty star-forming galaxies experiencing molecular inflow (Berta et al. 2021). 
  • Analysis of spectral line observations of the dusty star-forming galaxy ACT-S J0209941+001557, which demonstrated how pixel-based lens modeling can be used to recover nonparametric structures in source-plane channel maps (Rivera et al. 2019).
  • Development of a new method for modeling integral field observations of lensed systems that eliminates the need for making restrictive prior assumptions about intrinsic kinematics, and yields more accurate source reconstructions with improved noise and resolution properties (Young et al. 2022). This new modeling method supports observing strategies that prioritize spectral resolution over spatial resolution

The broader impacts of this project have included the research training of three undergraduate and three graduate student researchers at Rutgers University, of whom two are first-generation college students and four are members of groups that are underrepresented in the physical sciences. The three undergraduate students participated in professional development activities through the Aresty Research Center's Summer Science Research Program at Rutgers. Broader impacts also included the development of a one-credit seminar course for first-year undergraduate students. The seminar introduced 48 students over three years to the skills and qualities that are valuable in research (e.g., programming, teamwork, communication, and persistence in the face of obstacles), and the practical steps they could take at Rutgers to foster success in STEM majors and careers, through case studies and conversations with guest researchers from different STEM fields.
